presentation.title: Introduction
presentation.toc: APIs increasingly become the connective tissue of the Web in general, and the way how business is looking at their IT strategy and structure in particular. APIs are what both separate and connect collaborating and communicating peers: They facilitate loose coupling of service providers and consumers and thus strike a balance between the ability to collaborate and cooperate, while still maintaining independence and individual control.

presentation.title: Microservices
presentation.toc: Microservice Architecture and Microservices embrace a new style of IT development and culture that focuses on speed, safety, robustness, and scalability. Taking the ideas of agile development, CI/CD, and DevOps one step further, microservices embrace organizational changes as well, so that improved IT processes are not compromised by the side-effects of organizational realities.

ul.li: IT is the/a key factor for organizational fitness and sophistication
IT complexity increases, yet IT velocity should increase as well
IT landscapes need to adapt to shifting organizations/partners/strategies
The line between internal and external IT is increasingly blurred/shifting
Top-down design and control of complex systems is problematic
Reduce system size to the max and integrate into an ecosystem
Make the system implementations self-contained, self-sustaining, and independent
Cultivate organizational structures aligned with the system boundaries
Empower system developers/owners to make their own design decisions
Enforce system separation by disallowing shortcuts
Focus on team size and service scope to keep size small
Focus on effective ways to speed up service delivery
Focus on standalone-ability throughout a service's lifecycle
Focus on ecosystems of services to improve overall robustness
Focus on loose coupling so that the ecosystem is resilient

slide.title: One Definition: Goals
slide.p: An architectural style for building solutions as network-based systems of services modularized by domains in order to improve the solutions’ evolvability, deployability, composability, scalability, resiliency and replaceability

slide.title: Another Definition: Methods
slide.p: A microservice is an independently deployable component of bounded scope that supports interoperability through message-based communication. Microservice architecture is a style of engineering highly automated, evolvable software systems made up of capability-aligned microservices.

tr.td: A way to create more developers
A way to connect all these developers

ul.li: Reduce Cost
Increase Release Speed
Improve Resilience
Enable Visibility

ol.li: Support continuous process (Be able to do it over)
Improve team independence (Interdependent teams create interdependent systems)
Keep project scope small (Big problems/systems tend to shape-shift)

ul.li: Microservices are an investment and not a default choice
The cost is the need for advanced infrastructure and teams
The return is increased flexibility and agility
What are the prerequisites for considering microservices?

ol.li: Rapid Provisioning: Automated process to quickly create server infrastructure
Monitoring: Multi-level monitoring from service health to business-level logic
Rapid Deployment: Automated ways to quickly move from code to running services

ul.li: Moving to MSA is a transition process and not one Big Bang

li.q: Containerization is the gateway drug for microservices.

ul.li: Containers exist because of CI/CD (rapid deployment)
Containers allow agility on the development and deployment level
MSA allows agility on the service ecosystem level
MSA without (some form of) containerization is hard to imagine
There is no hard limit on the size of a Microservice
Domain limits (DDD) are a good starting point
Team size (Conway) is a good starting point
MSA tells you to keep services independent and agile
MSA is a continuous process of reassessing services and their utility
If a service is too big, split service and team and relaunch the new services
If granularity is too small, join teams and services and relaunch the new service
...but still not a simple answer to the how big? question
Loose coupling is essential and not an easy thing to get right
Microservice teams have complete authority over technology choices
But they have to develop and deploy according to MSA
Apart from being agile, the only visible part is the API
MSA critically depends on API strategy, design, and tooling
API quality is a critical factor for MSA landscape fitness
They combine some essential SE trends of the past decade
MSA results in service landscapes that can evolve and adapt faster and better
MSA has a lot of tunable knobs and not one correct setting for them
Transitioning to MSA is a gradual process and can take several years
